text: Among Trump ' s loudest screams as election day approaches, the electoral system is falsified and rampant by the falsification of voters. We have dismantled this idea in more than one way, but recently Trump presented several statistics to support his claim during a gathering in Cleveland, Ohio, on 23 October. One of those allegations was: "14% of non-citizens are registered to vote." We had the Trump note and we were concerned. We found that Trump refers to a study that has been criticized and refuted several times with regard to the methodology that he uses. Trump refuted Trump's evidence by citing an article published in 2014 on the monkey cage, a blog hosted by the Washington Post, and told his campaign PolityFact. The Code was an introduction to a study that discussed the potential impact of non-citizens in the November 2014 elections. The authors - Jesse Richman and David Ernest - identified more than 14 per cent of non-citizens in both the 2008 and 2010 samples and indicated that they were registered to vote. Richman and Ernst used data collected from an electoral study in the cooperative Congress of Harvard University (CCES). The couple concluded that the Centre's data provided "sufficient samples" for their research. Trump accurately refers to the study, but its results have been highly controversial. Three experts wrote a rebuttal to the results of the study following the appearance of the Post article, and the study produced another peer-reviewed article. The main issue addressed in the study is the size of the sample and the unreliable database of respondents on the Internet.
